results.title: Reptiles: a first film
results.creator_credit: George J. Holland, BFA Educational Media and Norman Bean Films
results.brief_description: Introduces basic information about the characteristics of reptiles: body temperature, skin types and habitats. Shows various reptiles in their natural environment including alligators, turtles, snakes and chameleons. Provides a recapitulation of the information presented. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Rendez-Vous a Bray = Meeting in Bray
results.brief_description:
Of Luxembourg nationality, Julien is not drafted for the First World War, and is therefore able to continue his piano lessons in Paris. His friend Jacques is a pilot doing service at the war front. One day, Julien receives a telegram in which Jacques invites him for a stay at his remote estate in Bray. Julien leaves to meet his friend, but Jacques does not show up. His only company at the lovely estate is a reticent woman whom, he assumes to be the housekeeper. By the time Julien decides to return to Paris, persuaded his friend has died in the war, he reads in the newspaper that the weather may have been the cause of Jacques’absence. Reference: Flanders International Film Festival (Ghent). http://www.surf-inn.be/Archieven/filmfestival/eng/program/filmlist/PBP/rendezvousbray.htm

Credits: Director, writer, Andre Delvaux ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet.
Cast: Bulle Ogier, Roger van Hool, Boby Lapointe, Jean Bouise, Anna Karina, Mathiey Carriere.

results.title: Bribie
results.creator_credit: Kevin Brady, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kevin Brady sets the record straight on the Battle of Bribie, considered to be the closest Australia got to losing a battle in Vietnam. His “digger’s account” illustrates the major obstacles and the bravery shown by the men, who were met with gunfire on landing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kevin Brady, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Remembering Uncle Jack Charles
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of a @NITV Tiktok of Uncle Jack Charles' speech accepting the National NAIDOC Male Elder Award in 2022.
results.brief_description:
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be aware that this video contains the name, image and voice of a deceased person.
ACMI mourns the passing of actor, musician and revered Aboriginal Elder, Uncle Jack Charles. The Boon Wurrung, Dja Dja Wurrung, Woiwurrung and Yorta Yorta “father of Black theatre” passed away aged 79.
In addition to his monumental contribution to theatre, film and music, Charles was a survivor of the Stolen Generations, and advocated tirelessly for the rights of incarcerated Indigenous people.
In 2022 he was awarded the National NAIDOC Male Elder Award, giving an acceptance speech that reflects his lifetime of staunch advocacy.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be aware that this video contains the name, image and voice of a deceased person.

Revered actor, musician and revered Aboriginal Elder, Uncle Jack Charles has sadly passed aged 79. The Boon Wurrung, Dja Dja Wurrung, Woiwurrung and Yorta Yorta “father of Black theatre” made a monumental contribution to theatre, film and music. He was a survivor of the Stolen Generations and advocated tirelessly for Indigenous rights, reflected in his acceptance speech for the 2022 National NAIDOC Male Elder Award.
description_for_label:
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be aware that this video contains the name, image and voice of a deceased person.

Revered actor, musician and revered Aboriginal Elder, Uncle Jack Charles has sadly passed aged 79. The Boon Wurrung, Dja Dja Wurrung, Woiwurrung and Yorta Yorta “father of Black theatre” made a monumental contribution to theatre, film and music. He was a survivor of the Stolen Generations and advocated tirelessly for Indigenous rights, reflected in his acceptance speech for 2022 the National NAIDOC Male Elder Award.

results.title: Growing up fast
results.creator_credit: John Croxford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It was itchy feet that encouraged John Croxford to join the Australian Navy. He spent most of his time patrolling the Korean coast where there was no room for mistakes.

results.title: Remembering Marilyn
results.creator_credit: Andrew Solt, Harry Arends, Susan F Walker, Asta Productions and Scotti-Vinnedge Productions
results.brief_description: Lee Remick hosts this tribute to screen goddess Marilyn Monroe, charting her rise to fame from her early years as struggling brunette photographer’s model to her later incarnation as a successful actress and blonde bombshell. This documentary examines the continuing appeal of Monroe and the private hell hidden behind the radiant public facade, and features rare footage of her teenage years, an early television commercial for Royal Triton Fuel, her appearance on the Jack Benny Show, her visit to Korea to perform for the American troops, her controversial rendition of Happy Birthday for President Kennedy, and clips from some of her most famous film roles. Also includes interviews with Gloria Steinem, Robert Wagner, Robert Mitchum, Susan Strasberg, and Monroe herself.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [November 2010]
results.brief_description: Nine Victorian war veterans tell of their experiences through the creation of digital stories, as part of ACMI’s Digital Storytelling workshop. While the horror and dangers and residual trauma of war are evident, these stories also pay tribute to the qualities of mateship and bravery instilled in them by the experience.

results.title: Remembering Life
results.brief_description: A history of Life magazine which first appeared in America in November 1936. Life pioneered pictorial journalism and in the process radically altered the course of the print media. Editors, journalists and photographers involved with its production, discuss the incredible power and influence had by this pictorial.
results.description: A history of Life magazine which first appeared in America in November 1936. Life pioneered pictorial journalism and in the process radically altered the course of the print media. Editors, journalists and photographers involved with its production, discuss the incredible power and influence had by this pictorial.

results.title: Remembering country
results.creator_credit: Kate Gillick, Harold Furber, Charlotte Seymour, Film Victoria and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: An autobiographical documentary which tells the story of a member of the ‘stolen generation’ of Aboriginal children of mixed descent. In 1957 at age four, Harold Furber was taken from the desert regions near Alice Springs by the Commonwealth Government, and placed in a Methodist missionary camp on Croker Island, 225 km north-east of Darwin. Telling his story through the use of slides and archival footage taken at the mission during the fifties and sixties, Furber recounts a childhood where his fragile but growing feeling of belonging to a new family and home on Croker Island, was continually shattered by the confusion and sense of loss and pain caused by his separation from his family and his country. Carrying a deep sense of alienation and bitterness into his adult life, Furber attempts through this documentary, to reconstruct his fractured identity by reconnecting with his birthplace and community. Narrated by Harold Furber. Written by Kate Gillick and Harold Furber.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kate Gillick, Harold Furber, Charlotte Seymour, Film Victoria and Australian Film Commission
